title: The man cleaning up by removing revenge porn
text:
“It’s become a hero category for Removify, if I could put it that way,” Bell says.

Getting offensive photos onto the internet is far easier than getting them off. A formal submission must be made to the publisher of the images; when that’s Facebook, your request will be put into a queue by a team of human moderators. “There’s no machine learning or automation around the publishers’ process,” Bell says.

I’ll be thinking, mate, why did you let a phone anywhere near you when you were doing that?

This makes requesting removal an ordeal that many victims struggle to face themselves. Bell charges nothing until the offending pictures are gone: a successful erasure campaign costs between $500 and $2500.

“A client will warn us there are some photos of them getting up to something pretty weird. And I’ll be thinking, mate, why did you let a phone anywhere near you when you were doing that?”

Regardless of the answer, Removify is there to help. And it’s helping lift Bell’s net worth from an estimated $170 million in 2018, to $217 million in this year’s Young Rich List placing him in 18th spot on the list.

Bell grew up on a sheep and cattle farm at Mount Macedon, north of Melbourne. His first business was selling extra sandwiches and snacks to his schoolmates that he’d convinced his mum to pack. “She just thought I was hungry,” he says. "And she made the best lunches."

The natural entrepreneur lasted six weeks in a university business degree, dropping out to take a job in recruitment – “that was my apprenticeship in cold-calling” – before starting a skincare business which he sold out of in 2010.

He studied the Google playbook and began cold-calling again, promising small businesses he found on the second page of searches that he could get them on to the first. Within a week he had his first paying customer, and WME was born.

Advertisement

“If they didn’t hang up on me straight away, I knew there was at least a sliver of interest. But you have to show value very, very quickly.”

Whenever he got a business owner to tell him what they were paying someone else per month for SEO, Bell would offer to halve it, and not charge until agreed objectives had been met. He still owns six international WME agencies and wants to be in 50 countries by 2023.

Nick Bell sees a big future for Removify in the US, where "anything goes" when it comes to defamation. Janie Barrett

After the sale of WME in 2017, Bell had planned a year off, but just three weeks in became restless to create a new enterprise. Removify now has 20 employees in Melbourne; offices are set to open in London in October, and Toronto in November. Growth prospects are good.

The criminalisation of revenge porn in Australia last year means that publishers bound to local laws will usually act on Removify’s takedown requests quickly, Bell says.

Meanwhile, defamation laws in Australia, Britain and Canada help to make malicious reviews vanish. “We’re a bit like a law firm in our knowledge of the platforms’ review policies.”

But what if the review is from a genuine customer? In those cases, Removify employs a tactic called “suppression”.

“Say you’ve got a guy who was done for tax fraud 10 years ago, he’s trying to rebuild his career and the first result on a search of his name is the Financial Review article on the old court case,” Bell says.

“We’ll gradually populate page one of the search results on his name with positive or neutral results about him, and push that article onto the second page.”

If that sounds a bit suspect, Bell feels no need to apologise. “The internet is an unfair and an unregulated place,” he says. “To the extent the whole thing’s a game, whoever plays best wins.”

With Bell claiming revenue had reached $1.5 million a month by its third month in business, Removify would appear to be winning. Indeed, Bell’s just getting started.

“The US is absolutely anything goes when it comes to defamation, so we think the suppression business there could be huge.”

description: Nick Bell first found success by accentuating the positive. Now he's found a niche in eliminating the negative, as Removify is in demand for revenge porn removal.
